articles.headline: U.N. Nuclear Agency Calls Iran Inquiry ‘Dead End’
articles.snippet: The declaration may help American efforts to have Russia and China join in approving new economic sanctions.
articles.abstract: The declaration may help American efforts to have Russia and China join in approving new economic sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The director general of the United Nations nuclear watchdog declared in unusually blunt language on Thursday that Iran had stonewalled investigators about evidence that the country had worked on nuclear weapons design, and that his efforts to reveal the truth had “effectively reached a dead end.”
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Obamas’ Uninvited Guests Prompt an Inquiry
articles.snippet: The Secret Service is investigating how a Virginia couple found their way into President Obama’s first state dinner.
articles.abstract: The Secret Service is investigating how a Virginia couple found their way into President Obama’s first state dinner.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Secret Service is investigating how a couple aspiring to be reality-show celebrities managed to appear at President Obama’s first state dinner without being on the guest list, provoking questions about security at the White House.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: HSBC Returns to Its Roots in Hong Kong
articles.snippet: Reeling from losses in subprime mortgages, the banking giant is moving its chief to Hong Kong and seeking growth in China and other emerging markets.
articles.abstract: Reeling from losses in subprime mortgages, the banking giant is moving its chief to Hong Kong and seeking growth in China and other emerging markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: HSBC is so tied to Hong Kong that when the bank’s shares dropped sharply earlier this year a local television commentator burst into tears while reporting the news.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Taliban Open Northern Front in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Militants have had a resurgence in Kunduz, a province that U.S. officials didn’t think they had to worry about.
articles.abstract: Militants have had a resurgence in Kunduz, a province that U.S. officials didn’t think they had to worry about.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  Far from the heartland of the Taliban insurgency in the south, this once peaceful northern province was one place American and Afghan officials thought they did not have to worry about.

articles.headline: Ex-UBS Banker Seeks Billions for Blowing Whistle
articles.snippet: Bradley C. Birkenfeld, who helped American clients illegally evade taxes and then helped the United States government find them, could reap a giant reward.
articles.abstract: Bradley C. Birkenfeld, who helped American clients illegally evade taxes and then helped the United States government find them, could reap a giant reward.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bradley C. Birkenfeld was sentenced to 40 months in prison for helping rich Americans dodge their taxes. Now he is hoping for a bit more  a few billion dollars more.

articles.headline: Dubai’s Move on Debt Rattles Markets Worldwide
articles.snippet: Dubai’s request to suspend debt repayments sent European markets spiraling downward, though some analysts suggested fears of contagion were unfounded.
articles.abstract: Dubai’s request to suspend debt repayments sent European markets spiraling downward, though some analysts suggested fears of contagion were unfounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Global financial markets swooned Thursday, with London seeing its most precipitous drop in nearly nine months, a day after Dubai stunned investors with the news that it was asking banks to allow its main investment vehicle, Dubai World, to suspend its debt repayments for six months.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Kate Galbraith

articles.headline: U.S. Unlikely to Use the Ethanol Congress Ordered
articles.snippet: When Congress mandated refiners blend more ethanol into gas, demand was growing. Then the recession hit.
articles.abstract: When Congress mandated refiners blend more ethanol into gas, demand was growing. Then the recession hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, Congress ordered the nation’s gasoline refiners to do something that is turning out to be mathematically impossible.

articles.headline: Keeping Derivatives in the Dark
articles.snippet: The attempt to regulate derivatives is one part of the Obama administration’s financial reform package that is most in jeopardy.
articles.abstract: The attempt to regulate derivatives is one part of the Obama administration’s financial reform package that is most in jeopardy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Opaque markets breed insider profits and abuse of investors. Sunshine can bring competition and lower costs even if regulators do little beyond letting the sunlight shine.

articles.headline: Russia and China Endorse Agency’s Rebuke of Iran
articles.snippet: Administration officials held up the United Nations nuclear watchdog’s action as a victory for President Obama’s efforts to woo Russia and China.
articles.abstract: Administration officials held up the United Nations nuclear watchdog’s action as a victory for President Obama’s efforts to woo Russia and China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United Nations nuclear watchdog demanded Friday that Iran immediately freeze operations at a once secret uranium enrichment plant, a sharp rebuke that bore added weight because it was endorsed by Russia and China.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Some Jostling, but Less of a Frenzy Among Shoppers
articles.snippet: On the nation’s most high-octane shopping day, tighter security was evident at Wal-Mart stores.
articles.abstract: On the nation’s most high-octane shopping day, tighter security was evident at Wal-Mart stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after an unfolding economic crisis sent consumers into shock, they ventured out Friday and opened their wallets a bit  still hunting bargains, but no longer quite so afraid to spend.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Rosenbloom and Christopher Maag
